application_details: water withdrawal limits based on historical usage

cause_of_action: Dispute over election results and interpretation of appeal timelines under the Election Regulations.
application_details: The applicants argued the appeal period should start after the run-off election.
decision_reasoning: Each election (general or run-off) is distinct, and the appeal period applies to the specific election being challenged. Evidence also showed no legitimate expectation was created by the electoral officer to delay appeals.
procedure_followed: Judicial review application filed by unsuccessful candidates challenging the electoral officer's decision not to appoint an Election Appeal Commission.
result_of_case: Application dismissed; appeal period determined to begin after the general election.

residency_requirements: three years of residence in four years under s. 5(1)(c) of Citizenship Act
standard_of_review: correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for residency determination

state_protection_analysis: state protection was available despite evidence of police ineffectiveness
reasonableness_standard: standard of review is reasonableness simpliciter
risk_of_persecution: dismissed claims of racially motivated crime

standard_of_review: Judicial review analyzed procedural fairness claims

legal_basis: Rule 456(3) and (4) of the Federal Court Rules
application_details: Mr. Moore has extensive experience (1965-1981) and is better informed about oil and gas issues than Mr. Eickmeier, but he is no longer employed by the Crown and unwilling to serve as deponent.
decision_reasoning: The application is dismissed as there is no assurance Mr. Moore is willing to serve or that the Crown has confidence in him binding the Crown.
procedure_followed: Plaintiffs applied under Rule 456(4), arguing Mr. Moore would expedite discovery. The court analyzed rules and case precedents.
result_of_case: Court denied the order, emphasizing unwillingness and lack of assurance regarding Mr. Moore’s role.

Different Crime.Crime Name: Being a Member of a Terrorist Group
risk_assessment: under surveillance for over a decade
credibility_findings: time and compliance suggest some conditions could be relaxed
balance_of_convenience: emphasis on balance between security risks and personal freedoms
complicity_in_crimes: alleged involvement in activities related to terrorism
security_certificate: post-2008 certificate alleging inadmissibility due to national security concerns
standard_of_proof: judicial review involved evidence presentation, oral arguments, and consideration of proportionality

risk_to_national_security: neutralize any danger posed by their release
evidence_provided: no evidence of association with terrorism since 2002
judicial_review_result: balancing liberty and security concerns, with ongoing judicial oversight

decision_reasoning: review based on trustworthiness, passage of time, and compliance
conclusion_outcome: allowed to stay home alone under certain conditions
denied other requests for increased mobility and activities

Different Crime.Crime Name: Being a Member of a Terrorist Group
procedural_fairness: Judicial review involved evidence presentation, oral arguments, and consideration of proportionality between danger and conditions.
risk_assessment: Mr. Harkat was deemed a threat to national security but has been under surveillance for over a decade with limited breaches.
decision_outcome: Conditions were partially relaxed, emphasizing balance between security risks and personal freedoms.
security_concerns: His credibility and trustworthiness remain concerns
court_ruling: The court allowed partial modifications, permitting Mr. Harkat to stay home alone under strict conditions and increasing weekly outings from three to five.

decision_conclusion: Governor in Council did not fulfill duty to act fairly

application_details: service on corporation by leaving document with person in charge at branch or agency in Canada
procedure_followed: court analyzed whether Manitoulin could be considered Topocean's branch or agency
